This interactive display project is founded, funded and run by students with the support of the school. Aimed to benefit staff, students and visitors, this project was started in January 2017 and the display was launched in August 2017. This system runs on an android TV box with an IR touchscreen. 

	All the apps are developed by our very own students, as personal projects, IRPs, or module projects integrated into our Computing Studies (CS) curriculum. We hope that this project will give our CS students an opportunity to contribute meaningfully to the school. 

	We appreciate the strong support from Senior Management, Estate team and IT department. We would also like to thank the CS department for their dedication towards CS education and their inspiration, guidance and support during this project. This project is not possible without their hard work.

Starting from a single CS teacher and two programming electives in 2008, CS education in NUS High School has grown rapidly in the past 10 years to the 6-year curriculum it is today. Since July 2017, Computing is an independent academic department in NUS High.


	Led by Mrs Phylliscia Lee, there are 4 passionate educators in the CS department, Mr Chua Eng Siong Claude, Mr Li Da and Mr Ng Chee Loong. With their diverse background and complementary
strengths, our CS teaching team provides a wide range of modules, with topics ranging from algorithmic skills to hands-on hardware, from mobile app development to data analytics.


	With the strong belief of cultivating computational thinking skills in every NUS High student, a core module “Computational Thinking” is offered to all Year 1 students. Via this module, students will be exposed to three key areas in Computer Science: 1) Problem Solving, 2) Programming Principles & Concepts and 3) Data Skills.


	In addition to the core academic curriculum, the department also offers various programmes to cater to different needs of students. They include:

		· Outreach activities such as CS Science Masterclass where NUS High CS students mentor and guide primary school children on related CS projects, and Values-In-Action projects where NUS High students conducts coding lessons or workshops for public.

		· Student Enrichment such as visits to infocomm companies like Google and talks conducted by CS Professors from Institutes of Higher Learning

		· Infocomm Competitions

		· Talent Development Programme where students passionate about algorithms will undergo Informatics Olympiad Training

resources.string: \tInfrared touch screens operate on the basis of light-beam interruption, commonly referred to as beam break, to determine the location of touch events. They are perimeter based but differ from other perimeter based technologies such as Surface Acoustic Wave, in that they use infrared light beams and not ultrasonic waves. \n\n\tIn infrared touch screens, Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) are placed on one side of the bezel and light sensors are placed on the opposite side in a one-to-one ratio. As an object touches the screen, it interrupts the light-beam causing a loss of light at the sensor. This loss of light is used to determine the location of the touch event. The LEDs and sensors are laid out in a grid so that each touch event breaks two beams, giving an X and a Y coordinate. These two coordinates are then correlated to determine the location of the touch occurring on the screen.
